author: Shruti Singh
text: login to www.scorhigh.com for Policy watch summary

author: Shashi Ketan Samal
text:
India's likely to install 54.7 GW wind capacity by 2022 against 60 GW target according to Fitch solution macro research. India has set a ambitious target of 175GW by 2022 - 100 Solar, 60GW - WInd,  10GW by bioenergy &  5GW by small hydro. However, agencies have also showed concerns on economic viability & auction of wind projects may be postponed 
 - Dec 2018 - 20GW wind capacity by 2020 but delays in implementation 

Wind Energy potential in India: 
 - India early starter - in 4th position wind generation capacity  
- Old wind power stations has very low capacity & technology - same place can be upgraded 
 - Unexplored area in oceans - in nascent stage
   Eastern side - cyclone prone but may be on western side - could be costly 

Policies available:
 - National wind power policy 
 - On shore & off shore 
 - Solar wind hybrid policy 
 - Oct 2015 - national offshore wind energy policy framework 
   7500 km long coastline - can tap energy from EEZ
 - National Institute of wind energy in Chennai - Potential in western states. 

Offshore wind energy: 
 - Made simple by scientific technology - floating windmills in EEZ below which turbine - transferring energy from underground turbine to underground collection centre. 
 - Europe is the leader: their tariffs is what India's on shore tariffs is 
   They were provided incentives early on.   
 - 30GW target by 2030 - offshore 
 - Need data localisation: Germany - took 8 yrs in gathering meteorological data, ocean data 
   Hence, needs high investment. 
 - takes time to understand business proposition. 
 - Offshore - 10000cr govt allocation by clean energy fund - collected by coal cess 
   pilot projects by national wind energy institute. 

Onshore Wind energy: 
 - Support infrastructure.  
 - Grid develop - developers responsibility : delinking grid development Europe has done 
 - offshore has potential but time to come up. 
 - Competition with Solar - Re 2.33 for solar, wind - Rs.4.50. So solar getting pull from market side. 
 - Growth rate has reduced as compared to solar 

Challenges in wind sector: 
 - lull in wind power sector for past 3 yrs. 
 - Transition phase in policy: incentives like accelerated depreciation - gradually taken away 
 - auctioning of wind projects: tariff determination process - Rs 2.4   
   wind is location specific - bidders not able to match govt. tariffs. 
 - DISCOM risks - continuous curtailment of power generation 
 - delayed payment that developers grappling 
 - Capacity allocation - govt need to trust market. 
   competitive prices - prices can go up due to international market change - should be acceptable
    
 Future policy & Paris INDC: 
 - 2027 - from 175 GW to 275 GW from renewable energy 
 - commitment to Paris - INDC - reducing emissions intensity of its GDP by 33 to 35 per cent by 2030 below 2005 levels
 - 40% will come from non fossil fuel sector - solar, hydro, nuclear 

Unprecedented Solar growth:  175GW mission mode target. 
 - SECI setup 
 - methodological approach. 
 - prices of panel in world were falling: Rs 14/unit to Rs 2.5/unit in 8yrs 
 - supported by incentive driven by market 
 - capital incentive is waived off - tariff supporting is own 

Future Steps: 
 - There is a benefit in developing solar & wind energy in a complementary manner. 
   wind is better in night or during monsoons & solar in summer & day time. 
   Better grid management 
 - enhancing storage & thermal flexibility. 
   solar thermal tech - molten salt can store energy and have at night 
 - Battery project: driving down costs in storage 
 - Develop on shore first, replace old places with new technology & tap the offshore wind. 

India is on track in achieving the Paris climate target. It needs to be far more ambitious & be a global leader in phasing out fossil fuels completely
